items.title: New release?
items.body: `wheel` moved to `packaging` in https://github.com/pypa/wheel/pull/346 but hasn't done a release since. That switch means `abi3` tags on Windows will now work, so it'd be great to see a release soon! Thanks for the work on this project 😄

items.title: wheel pack does not regenerate top_level.txt
items.body:
Running `wheel unpack`, adding a top-level module to the wheel, and repacking the wheel, does not update `top_level.txt` in dist-info.  e.g.
```
$ pip download wheel && wheel unpack *.whl && rm *.whl
$ echo 42 > wheel-0.34.2/foobar.py
$ wheel pack wheel-0.34.2
```
then examining the contents of top_level.txt in the repacked wheel shows that `foobar` was not added.

On a personal python module, we add scripts on _package_data_. They have execution permissions, but when installing a module from a whl they are lost.

This started on version > 0.33.6, I am building with python 3.6.8

items.title: use packaging.tags instead of pep425tags?
items.body:
pip has moved to using the pypa/packaging package instead of pep425tags.py. Is there interest in moving wheel to use that as well? Should it be vendored or listed as a dependent package? I think a dependent package would be better, since it should be safe to assume a working pip exists when wheel is installed.

I am particularly interested in improving PEP 600 support for `manlinux_X_Y` wheels, see pypa/packaging#280, pypa/manylinux#494

Edit: fix link

items.title: Use regular PEP 425 interpreter tags for PyPy wheels
items.body:
We'd like to go back to using standard PEP 425 tags for PyPy wheels (see https://github.com/pypa/packaging/issues/233 and https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/7629), but that entails having PyPy *build* wheels with the regular leading interpreter tag, rather than the current PyPy specific one.

I'm working on a PR to temporarily add back support for the custom tags to `pip`, but would also like to contain the problem on the `wheel` side, and will post a PR for that shortly.

items.title: pip 20 and pypy - changes needed to pep425tags.py
items.body:
pip20 now uses packaging.tags, not pep425tags.py, but wheel does not seem to have made that change yet. This breaks building wheels for PyPy, since the semantics of the python tag changed. 
At a minimum, the pypy-specific stanza should be removed from [`get_impl_version_info`](https://github.com/pypa/wheel/blob/master/wheel/pep425tags.py#L53), so the implementation becomes a one-liner `sys.version_info[0], sys.version_info[1]`. Are there plans to transition wheel to packaging.tags?

~Is there a way to add PyPy to the testing matrix for wheel?~

See pypa/packaging#233, pypa/packaging#184, and pypa/pip#7629

items.title: Building wheel from read-only source on Windows gives "Access Denied" on cleanup
items.body:
When building a wheel from read-only source files (ex. files checked into Perforce), with package_data set, and on Windows, a call to `python setup.py bdist_wheel` will finish with

> error: [WinError 5] Access is denied: 'build\\bdist.win32\\wheel\\mypkg\\some_file.txt'

This is due to the read-only attribute getting passed along for package_data files during the build and install steps (see https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/issues/1424 for reference). When bdist_wheel attempts to clean up at the end of the command via 
https://github.com/pypa/wheel/blob/882650d0fd2fadd75f4ea7c5d6b62f15f81b398a/wheel/bdist_wheel.py#L270
the read-only flags will trigger an access denied exception.

According to the official docs for shutil (https://docs.python.org/3/library/shutil.html#rmtree-example), when calling `shutil.rmtree` on Windows it's necessary to have an onerror callback to deal with read-only files.

items.title: Append build number to the `WHEEL` file through `wheel pack`
items.body:
When `bdist_wheel` is invoked, it appends a build number to the `WHEEL` file in `dist-info`. Do you think it makes sense to bring the behavior of `wheel pack` on par with `bdist_wheel` by appending/modifying this tag?

Currently, a package which is installed through a wheel, loses the information related to the wheel it was installed from. Extending `wheel pack` to behave similarly allows debugging of regressed wheels.

Example of what `python setup.py bdist_wheel --build-number=2` generates 
```
Wheel-Version: 1.0
Generator: bdist_wheel (0.33.6)
Root-Is-Purelib: true
Build: 2
Tag: py3-none-any
```

items.title: MacOS Platform tag when MACOSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET is set
items.body:
On MacOs., by default Platform Tag is set to Python platform tag version https://docs.python.org/3/distutils/apiref.html#distutils.util.get_platform

But developer can set  MACOSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET to another version (eg, to use newer API). So can build python package which will not work on MacOs version suggested by platform tag. 

Of course it can be overwritten by `-p` flag, but I think that it should be out of box. 

Maybe some change like (https://github.com/pypa/wheel/blob/master/wheel/pep425tags.py):
```python 
def get_platform():
    """Return our platform name 'win32', 'linux_x86_64'"""
    # XXX remove distutils dependency
    result = distutils.util.get_platform()
    if result.startswith("macosx-") and "MACOSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET" in os.environ:
        result.rfind()
        tag = result[7:result.rfind("-")]
        parsed_tag = tuple(map(int, tag.split(".")))
        parsed_target = tuple(map(int, os.environ["MACOSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET"].split(".")))
        if parsed_tag < parsed_target:
            result = "macosx-" + os.environ["MACOSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET"] + result[result.rfind('-'):]
    result = result.replace('.', '_').replace('-', '_')
    if result == "linux_x86_64" and sys.maxsize == 2147483647:
        # pip pull request #3497
        result = "linux_i686"
    return result
```

items.title: allow changing the build base
items.body:
I would like to move out the ``build`` folder from the root of the project. Therefore I'm requesting a ``--build-base`` flag that would allow the caller to specify the build folder location. 

The ``build`` folder this is set by https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/master/Lib/distutils/command/build.py#L101-L108, and the default is ``build`` per https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/master/Lib/distutils/command/build.py#L57. Now, this folder is configurable though:

```bash
python3.7 setup.py build --help                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       
Options for 'MyBuild' command:
  --build-base (-b)  base directory for build library
```

What I'm asking here is to make this controllable from the bdist_wheel entry point too. This package is calling the ``bdist`` that calls ``build``. When we do these calls we should forward our ``--build-base``.

items.title: Wheel build failure on AIX with 0.33.2
items.body:
The latest release introduces a bug on AIX which results in the following error when closing the wheel archive:

`error: 'L' format requires 0 <= number <= 4294967295`

The issue can be reliably reproduced by running the test suite on AIX. The full traceback from the `test_wheelfile.py - test_directories` test:

```
   def test_directories(tmpdir, wheel_path):
        """
        The WheelFile should contain entries for directories,
        empty and not.
        """
        build_dir = tmpdir
        sub_dir = build_dir / 'sub'
        sub_dir.mkdir()
        (sub_dir / '__init__.py').write_text('', encoding='utf-8')
        empty_dir = build_dir / 'empty'
        empty_dir.mkdir()

        with WheelFile(wheel_path, 'w') as wf:
>           wf.write_files(str(build_dir))

tests/test_wheelfile.py:191:
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _
/opt/bb/lib/python2.7/zipfile.py:801: in __exit__
    self.close()
wheel/wheelfile.py:181: in close
    ZipFile.close(self)
...
                    try:
                        filename, flag_bits = zinfo._encodeFilenameFlags()
                        centdir = struct.pack(structCentralDir,
                        stringCentralDir, create_version,
                        zinfo.create_system, extract_version, zinfo.reserved,
                        flag_bits, zinfo.compress_type, dostime, dosdate,
                        zinfo.CRC, compress_size, file_size,
                        len(filename), len(extra_data), len(zinfo.comment),
                        0, zinfo.internal_attr, zinfo.external_attr,
>                       header_offset)
E                       error: 'L' format requires 0 <= number <= 4294967295

/opt/bb/lib/python2.7/zipfile.py:1315: error
```

I believe this is due to https://github.com/pypa/wheel/pull/289. The root cause seems to be something with the attributes set on the directory entries on the zip archive. The following patch fixes the issue:

```
diff --git a/wheel/wheelfile.py b/wheel/wheelfile.py
index 93b4bfa..579e179 100644
--- a/wheel/wheelfile.py
+++ b/wheel/wheelfile.py
@@ -145,7 +145,6 @@ class WheelFile(ZipFile):
     def mkdir(self, filename, arcname):
         st = os.stat(filename)
         zinfo = ZipInfo(arcname + '/', date_time=get_zipinfo_datetime(st.st_mtime))
-        zinfo.external_attr = st.st_mode << 16
         zinfo.compress_type = ZIP_DEFLATED
         self.writestr(zinfo, b'')
```

I will have to investigate further to determine what exactly is happening here.

items.title: Wheels should include entries for directories
items.body:
As [discovered here](https://github.com/pypa/packaging-problems/issues/212#issuecomment-487138721), the wheel library, when producing a wheel, omits entries in the zip file for the directories present in the tree. This behavior has the unfortunate consequence of making PEP 420 namespace packages, which would otherwise be available through the normal importlib machinery, to be unreachable.

My recommendation, therefore, despite the fact that [there is no supported container format](https://github.com/pypa/packaging-problems/issues/244) and [wheels are explicitly discouraged for this use](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0427/#id24), is that wheel should include directory entries in the zip files it creates. Doing so would shorten the divergence from eggs, align the format with the consensus convention, and enable certain features to just work.

items.title: wheel pack --build-number=...
items.body:
One (The main?) use of wheel unpack/wheel pack would be to fix a broken wheel and repack it without invoking the build chain.  If the broken wheel has already been uploaded on PyPI, the new wheel needs to use a (higher) build number.
It would thus seem useful to be able to set this wheel number from `wheel pack --build-number=...`, rather than having to rename the wheel manually.

items.title: TypeError: must be type, not classobj
items.body:
As of version 0.32.0 of wheel, the WheelFile class is now a subclass of ZipFile. This is a problem because ZipFile, which comes from the zipfile module in the std lib, was an old-style class up to python 2.7.3, and did not become new-style until 2.7.4.

So if using wheel >= 0.32.0 with python < 2.7.4, any calls to super() inside the WheelFile class will result in an error:

`TypeError: must be type, not classobj`

The wheel package needs to either avoid making any calls to super() in WheelFile to retain support for older versions of python, or it should explicitly declare in its setup.py that it no longer supports python < 2.7.4.

items.title: `WheelFile` moved location between 0.31.1 and 0.32.0, breaking user code
items.body:
I have, for a long time, been using `WheelFile` in:

* https://github.com/matthew-brett/multibuild/blob/devel/supported_wheels.py#L8
* The delocate package: https://github.com/matthew-brett/delocate

Both of these are fairly widely used.  At some point between 0.31.2 and 0.32.0, `WheelFile` appears to have moved from the `install` module to the `wheelfile` module, thus breaking imports for both bits of code.   Of course, I can work round this with some conditional imports, and new releases of these packages, but it would help if you would consider deprecation warnings or similar before moving stuff around in the public API.

See: https://github.com/matthew-brett/multibuild/issues/202

items.title: How should a PEP 508 requirement with an URL specifier be handled?
items.body:
Starting with pip 10.0, requirements with [URL specifiers](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0508/#examples) are now supported (as replacement for dependency links).

With the following sample project' `setup.py`:
```python
from setuptools import setup

setup(name='projecta', version='42',
      install_requires='''
      lazyImport@git+https://gitlab.com/KOLANICH1/lazyImport.py.git#egg=lazyImport-dev
      ''')
```

Installing from source work, but looking at the generated wheel metadata:
```shell
> python setup.py -q bdist_wheel && unzip -p dist/projecta-42-py3-none-any.whl '*/METADATA'
Metadata-Version: 2.1
Name: projecta
Version: 42
Summary: Description!
Home-page: UNKNOWN
Author: UNKNOWN
Author-email: UNKNOWN
License: UNKNOWN
Platform: UNKNOWN
Requires-Dist: lazyImport

UNKNOWN
```

It works with the following patch:
```diff
 tests/test_metadata.py | 3 +++
 wheel/metadata.py      | 2 ++
 2 files changed, 5 insertions(+)

diff --git i/tests/test_metadata.py w/tests/test_metadata.py
index 3421430..2390e98 100644
--- i/tests/test_metadata.py
+++ w/tests/test_metadata.py
@@ -9,6 +9,7 @@ def test_pkginfo_to_metadata(tmpdir):
         ('Provides-Extra', 'test'),
         ('Provides-Extra', 'signatures'),
         ('Provides-Extra', 'faster-signatures'),
+        ('Requires-Dist', "pip @ https://github.com/pypa/pip/archive/1.3.1.zip"),
         ('Requires-Dist', "ed25519ll; extra == 'faster-signatures'"),
         ('Requires-Dist', "keyring; extra == 'signatures'"),
         ('Requires-Dist', "keyrings.alt; extra == 'signatures'"),
@@ -28,6 +29,8 @@ def test_pkginfo_to_metadata(tmpdir):
 
     egg_info_dir = tmpdir.ensure_dir('test.egg-info')
     egg_info_dir.join('requires.txt').write("""\
+pip@ https://github.com/pypa/pip/archive/1.3.1.zip
+
 [faster-signatures]
 ed25519ll
 
diff --git i/wheel/metadata.py w/wheel/metadata.py
index 4fa17cd..5b03e3e 100644
--- i/wheel/metadata.py
+++ w/wheel/metadata.py
@@ -17,6 +17,8 @@
 
 def requires_to_requires_dist(requirement):
     """Compose the version predicates for requirement in PEP 345 fashion."""
+    if requirement.url:
+        return " @ " + requirement.url
     requires_dist = []
     for op, ver in requirement.specs:
         requires_dist.append(op + ver)
```

```shell
> python setup.py -q bdist_wheel && unzip -p dist/projecta-42-py3-none-any.whl '*/METADATA'
Metadata-Version: 2.1
Name: projecta
Version: 42
Summary: Description!
Home-page: UNKNOWN
Author: UNKNOWN
Author-email: UNKNOWN
License: UNKNOWN
Platform: UNKNOWN
Requires-Dist: lazyImport @ git+https://gitlab.com/KOLANICH1/lazyImport.py.git

UNKNOWN
```

Unfortunately, this is technically not valid [PEP 345](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0345/#requires-dist-multiple-use) metadata.

items.body: If I run `python setup.py build bdist_wheel` twice without changing any files, the resulting wheels have binary differences.  This seems a bit unexpected given that other archive tools like tar are idempotent. Is there a reason for this? I tested on python 2 and 3.

items.title: Wheel fails without useful error message when --wheel-dir not writable
items.body:
When wheel is invoked specifying a non-writable destination directory with `--wheel-dir`, it fails but doesn't give an error indicating the cause of the failure.

```
$ pip3 wheel --wheel-dir=not_writable_directory .
Processing /home/user/example_pkg
Building wheels for collected packages: example-pkg
  Running setup.py bdist_wheel for example-pkg ... done
  Running setup.py clean for example-pkg
Failed to build example-pkg
ERROR: Failed to build one or more wheels
```

Adding `-vvv` to the `pip3` command line provides more output but still no useful error message.

I would expect to see something like:

```
Failed to write not_writable_directory/example_pkg-0.0.1-py3-none-any.whl: permission denied
```

Reproducable using the minimal example at https://packaging.python.org/tutorials/packaging-projects/.

items.title: Failure to include extension modules when ~/.pydistutils.cfg sets `[build_ext] inplace = true`
items.body:
I have a ~/.pydistutils.cfg (https://docs.python.org/3/install/index.html#location-and-names-of-config-files) with the following contents:
```
[build_ext]
force = true
inplace = true
```
(essentially allowing me to type `python setup.py build_ext` instead of `python setup.py build_ext --force --inplace`; the former because I use ccache to cache my compilations anyways and many packages don't declare source dependencies properly (causing distutils's timestamp scheme to fail) and the latter because I have a lot of editable-installed, with-extension packages.)

When the `inplace = true` line is added, trying to build a wheel for e.g. numpy, pandas, or various other common scientific python packages from a source checkout (`python setup.py bdist_wheel`) fails to include the `.so` files in the wheel (thus generating an incorrect wheel).  Removing the `inplace = true` line fixes the issue.  (Unfortunately, I was not able to reproduce the issue using smaller, minimal examples.)

I'm not exactly sure what the underlying issue is, but I'd guess that when `wheel` is invoking `build_ext`, it should make sure that `--inplace` is not set (asusming that that's indeed the problem)?

items.title: Inconsistency between bdist_wheel and rotate with underscores/hyphens
items.body:
I fear that this might be closed as "not a bug" either for the wheel or the setuptools package. Anyway, I've stumbled over the effect and would like to at least leave something to find for anybody also experiencing the effect.

Unzip [inconsistency.zip](https://github.com/pypa/wheel/files/2083904/inconsistency.zip) to get a dummy setup where the key part in setup.py is:

    setup(
      name="foo-bar",
      ...
    )

When executing `setup.py bdist_wheel` I get a file called `foo_bar-1-py3-none-any.whl` (with an underscore).

However when running `setup.py rotate --match .whl --keep 0` to throw away previous wheel builds it won't work. The reason is pretty obvious because the screen output says:

    running rotate
    running egg_info
    writing foo_bar.egg-info\PKG-INFO
    writing dependency_links to foo_bar.egg-info\dependency_links.txt
    writing top-level names to foo_bar.egg-info\top_level.txt
    reading manifest file 'foo_bar.egg-info\SOURCES.txt'
    writing manifest file 'foo_bar.egg-info\SOURCES.txt'
    0 file(s) matching foo-bar*.whl

Note the `foo-bar*.whl` in the last line...

The behavior of rotate is consistent with the names of what `setup.py sdist` creates, thus I concluded that it would rather be a problem of wheel than of setuptools.

I have setuptools version 39.2.0 and wheel version 0.31.1 installed.

items.title: Updates for PEP 566
items.body:
I didn't think `wheel` needed any additional updates to support [PEP 566](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0566/) , but over at https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/pull/1286, @brainwane pointed out that `wheel` creates a `DESCRIPTION.rst` file.

It seems like if the user is providing `Description-Content-Type`, `wheel` should output the correct extension, (e.g. `DESCRIPTION.md`) instead.

However, I'm not really sure what this file is used for (especially because the `Description` is included as the message body in `METADATA` as well) so I'm hesitant to propose to change it in case some downstream tool is expecting `DESCRIPTION.rst` to exist.

Why does wheel create this file? Is it reasonable to change the extension if we know it to be incorrect?

items.title: Archive Names can Break Paths - observed on MSYS2 (Windows)
items.body:
Attempting to build a wheel on Windows under [MSYS2](https://www.msys2.org) will fail because a base filename is generated which includes `'/'` characters.

```
...
creating build/bdist.mingw64_nt-6.1-2.10.0(0.325/5/3)-x86_64/wheel/uWebSockets-0.14.6a1.dist-info/WHEEL
creating '/e/uWebSockets-bindings/python/dist/uWebSockets-0.14.6a1-cp36-cp36m-mingw64_nt_6_1_2_10_0(0_325/5/3)_x86_64.whl' and adding '.' to it
error: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/e/uWebSockets-bindings/python/dist/uWebSockets-0.14.6a1-cp36-cp36m-mingw64_nt_6_1_2_10_0(0_325/5/3)_x86_64.whl'
```

This appears to be an indirect result of MSYS2 or MinGW including `'/'` characters in their platform name version string
```
$ uname -a
MINGW_NT-6.1 windoze 2.10.0(0.325/5/3) 2018-02-09 15:25 x86_64 Msys
```

The string is generated in [`get_archive_basename`](https://github.com/pypa/wheel/blob/3a87ecebaba765475392ae2cdfa2a51cb78360e0/wheel/bdist_wheel.py#L187) and the error occurs in  [`make_wheelfile_inner`](https://github.com/pypa/wheel/blob/812d4de33d91de2a1dbab57f2f58329c54ccd346/wheel/archive.py#L25)

Probably the fault of MSYS2 for generating a stupid platform name, but some sort of work around would be appreciated.

items.title: Pip install w/ --use-wheel doesn't work over HTTP/HTTPS
items.body:
I'm trying to setup a wheelhouse for pip to be used by CI and devs. It works just fine as long as I use a local repository, i.e.:

```
$ pip install \
    --use-wheel \
    --no-index \
    --find-links=/tmp/wheelhouse \
    -r requirements.txt`
```

However, when I try the same installation using HTTP/HTTPS, it fails. 

As per the [instructions](https://wheel.readthedocs.io/en/stable/), the command should work as follows:

```
$ pip install \
    --use-wheel \
    --no-index \
    --find-links=http://someserver \
    -r requirements.txt
```

However, I just end up getting `DistributionNotFound: No matching distribution found for [...]`.

I spent some time troubleshooting this and found that it doesn't even try to reach the remote server. 

I reproduced it by doing the following:

 * Spin up local Nginx server through Docker (`docker run -d -p 8080:80  nginx`)
 * Copy in your wheel files to `/usr/share/nginx/html` inside the container
 * Verify that the wheel files are accessible from the outside (`curl -I http://localhost:8080/foobar.whl`)
 * Now run pip and try to install a wheel file with:

```
$ pip install \
    --use-wheel \
    --no-index \
    --find-links=http://someserver:8080 \
    foobar
```

What's important to note here is that if you check the Nginx logs, there is no request that hits the server at all.

items.body:
Hello,

I'm currently packaging [psycopg2 as wheel](https://github.com/psycopg/psycopg2-wheels/) but the package has problems because the depending libraries include `libssl`, which can conflict with the system libssl, e.g. used by `urllib` (see psycopg/psycopg2#543). Unfortunately libssl doesn't have a standard ABI, so I don't think the situation can be solved.

Wheels have made life easier for a lot of people, allowing people to install the package without its build and runtime requirements, but because the resulting package is not reliable, and unfortunately it shows unreliability in situations easier to meet in production than in development/testing (it is a concurrency problem) it cannot be the default installation method.

I would like to make the wheel optional, i.e. `pip install psycopg2` should attempt to install the package from source, and in order to get the wheel some command line switch should be used, e.g. `pip install --binary psycopg2`. Is there any provision for this?

Alternatively I'm planning to release a separate package, `psycopg2-binary` and propose its installation in the `setup.py` if the build prerequisites are not met. Is this my only/best option?

Thank you.

items.title: "and extra" breaks environment marker logic
items.body: In pypa/setuptools#1242, we discovered that wheel is allegedly simply appending ` and extra=="..."`, which will break the logic when the existing environment marker contains or expressions.

items.title: Wheel tool generates broken wheels with two sets of metadata referring to different releases
items.body:
When building my pure Python project with

>>> python setup.py build sdist bdist_wheel

the wheel contains two sets of metadata: one for the version specified in setup.py, say, 0.8, one for the previously built version, say, 0.7.0. I consider such wheel as broken. It messes up the deployment process: 

When I attempt to deploy the sdist and wheel on pypi, v0.8 is correctly registered, and the sdist is properly uploaded and published. But twine tells warehouse to place the broken whel in the 0.7 release. 

See 
https://github.com/pypa/warehouse/issues/2675

for more details.

I don't even know how to clean up the resulting mess as I cannot upload the wheel for 0.8 to the right place as warehouse complains that there is already the same wheel. I'd have to remove the 0.8 wheel from the 0.7 release page etc. 

I would be surprised if I were the first to report this as my dev cycle should be normal. Well, I tend to forget bumping the version to something like 0.8dev after a release. But I do not think this should confuse the tool chain.

I have opened a related issue at
https://github.com/pypa/twine/issues/284

items.title: egg2dist solicits distinfo_path from two places
items.body:
Discovered in pypa/setuptools#1196, it seems that the egg2dist function both accepts a parameter distinfo_path but also accesses self.distinfo_dir. When egg2dist is invoked from an external caller like setuptools, and distinfo_dir isn't set, and the license text functionality is triggered, the function will crash with a TypeError.

egg2dist should either only use distinfo_path passed as a parameter or use the instance attribute. Even better, if possible, egg2dist should be refactored such that it doesn't depend on instance attributes at all (and thus can be a classmethod).

items.title: Implementation of ABI tags not well-defined
items.body: The exact value of ABI tags seems to be not well-defined in PEP 427 / PEP 491. It is derived from the `sysconfig` variable `SOABI`, but the exact derivation from that seems implementation-dependent. The [current implementation](https://github.com/pypa/wheel/blob/master/wheel/pep425tags.py#L90) takes a `SOABI` value such as `cpython-35m-darwin` and converts it to `cp35m`, dropping the `-darwin`, but presumably this has a meaning which shouldn't be lost. What's the rationale for this particular way of deriving the tag, rather than say converting to `cp35m-darwin` which doesn't lose information about the underlying Python ABI?

items.title: Automatically detect limited ABI tags

milestone.description: First SemVer based release. Cuts out any unused and unnecessary features. Documentation overhauled to conform to the PyPA guidelines.

items.body: Wheel should be able to access the `Extension` objects during `bdist_wheel` and detect if all of them use the limited ABI. In such cases, the limited ABI tag should be applied automatically, possibly obviating the need for `--python-limited-abi`.

items.title: Limit the scope of "wheel install"

milestone.description: First SemVer based release. Cuts out any unused and unnecessary features. Documentation overhauled to conform to the PyPA guidelines.

items.body: The `wheel install` command was added as a proof of concept implementation before wheel installation support was added to pip. Daniel has argued that we should keep this functionality, although I'm not quite sure why. If I were a developing a tool for installing distributions, I would rather look at pip than wheel for an example. If we are to keep `wheel install`, I think it should be a bare-bones installer that only unpacks the wheel contents to their proper locations and installs any console scripts. Handling dependencies or requirements files is just an unnecessary maintenance burden that ultimately serves nobody's interests.

items.title: Remove or deprecate wheel signing features

milestone.description: First SemVer based release. Cuts out any unused and unnecessary features. Documentation overhauled to conform to the PyPA guidelines.

items.body: Signing wheels does not actually help a lot, as there is no infrastructure for distributing the authors' public keys. For this reason, I am in favor of getting rid of the signing features until such time that they can be replaced with something that provides real security benefits. Keeping `wheel sign` could be even dangerous as it may lull users into a false sense of security, thinking they or their users are better protected if they sign their wheels.

items.title: Remove metadata.json from the generated files in .dist-info
items.body: As PEP 426 was never accepted, I don't feel like we should generate this file anymore in the `.dist-info` directory in the wheel file.

items.title: Wheel now depends on OrderedDict, not present in Python 2.6
items.body:
I guess this may be intended, but the new release of Wheel does not work with Python 2.6 unmodified, because it has:

```
from collections import OrderedDict
```

in "wheel/util.py", line 8 . I'm just flagging that in case it wasn't intended ...

https://travis-ci.org/matthew-brett/multibuild/jobs/274160483#L137

items.title: Package description is corrupted when a line starts with "From "
items.body:
When a wheel is build and the file `METADATA` is written, all lines starting with `From ` are prefixed with a `>`. For example, [this line of my README file](https://github.com/jobec/rfc5424-logging-handler/blame/07dbbe63f9a08ba962587dbab796cb0d62c34971/README.rst#L133) is changed from
```
From a logging config dictionary
```
into
```
>From a logging config dictionary
```
Turning it into invalid reStructuredText. This description ends up in the file `DESCRIPTION.rst` and eventually turned my package description on PyPi into garbage.

I traced the issue back to [this specific line](https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/d0e61bded5256e775e470e2c0da22367a1a81970/Lib/email/generator.py#L245) in the standard python `email.generator` module.

Of course, rewriting that section title fixes things, but this is one hell of a nasty bug to bump into. Nobody expects his package description to be handled like and email 🤔

items.title: PYPY: running wheel on PyPy and PEP 425 to create packages with binary info
items.body:
Originally reported by: **mattip (Bitbucket: [mattip](https://bitbucket.org/mattip), GitHub: [mattip](https://github.com/mattip))**

----------------------------------------

[PEP 425](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0425/#python-tag) specifies a Python Tag of the form cp27 for CPython and pp27 for PyPy, but in practice a pure-python wheel packaged by PyPy can run on CPython (and more importantly visa-versa). Wheel currently marks packages produced on PyPy with sys.pypy_version_info() which is not related at all to the sys.version_info() python language implementation.

For packages that contain binary CFFI or CAPI extensions, an additional [ABI tag](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0425/#abi-tag) is also provided, this IMO should not change from current usage. There is a question what the Python Tag should be for such a package, today it is too specific and contians the entire sys.pypy_version_info(), IMO it should reflect best practices on CPython which would lead to pp27 for python 2.7, pp35 or pp36 for the python 3.5 and 3.6 interpreter.

items.title: Order of files in the generated ZIP file is indeterministic
items.body:
Originally reported by: **Matthias Bach (Bitbucket: [MatthiasBach](https://bitbucket.org/MatthiasBach), GitHub: Unknown)**

----------------------------------------

While the order of entries in the RECORDS files [is explicitly made deterministic](https://bitbucket.org/pypa/wheel/commits/4081620073cf527195e696d646c601fc834bdf3e), everything but the dist-info directory [is written to the generated ZIP file in random order](https://bitbucket.org/pypa/wheel/src/54ddbcc9cec25e1f4d111a142b8bfaa163130a61/wheel/archive.py?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#archive.py-63). Technically it relies on `os.walk`, but [that gives an undefined order](https://docs.python.org/3/library/os.html#os.listdir). When attempting to create reproducible builds this can cause builds on different working copies to produce wheels with different check sums. Sadly this is pretty hard to test for, as given the unspecified order of `os.walk` there is no definitive way to mess it up.

This is breaking the result from ``pep425tags.get_supported()``, it needs another clause around line 62 to handle the returned value.

While there are some tests that fail when run with a pypy interpreter, the failures do not seem to be caused by this particular issue.

items.title: bdist_wheel silently discards PEP 508 environment markers
items.body:
Originally reported by: **Nathaniel Smith (Bitbucket: [njs](https://bitbucket.org/njs), GitHub: [njs](https://github.com/njs))**

----------------------------------------

PEP 508 is the current law for how environment markers (conditional dependencies) are supposed to work, and it supports a syntax like:
```python
setup(...
    install_requires=[
        "cffi; os_name == 'nt'",
    ]
)
```

pip and setuptools understand this fine (e.g. `pip install my-sdist.tar.gz` correctly install `cffi` on Windows but not on other platforms). But bdist_wheel doesn't -- it silently discards the environment marker part, so that my wheel's METADATA says
```
Requires-Dist: cffi
```

I see that there's this [other weird extras-based thing](https://wheel.readthedocs.io/en/latest/#defining-conditional-dependencies) that bdist_wheel apparently supports, but it would sure be nice if it also supported the less-weird more-standard PEP 508 style :-).

items.title: wheel.pkginfo.write_pkg_info should set mangle_from_ to False; the default causes rendering issues
items.body:
Originally reported by: **Jason Madden (Bitbucket: [jamadden](https://bitbucket.org/jamadden), GitHub: [jamadden](https://github.com/jamadden))**

----------------------------------------

# Long Description

There was [a bug report against twine](https://github.com/pypa/twine/issues/227) where a user complained that  the description for an uploaded project was rendered incorrectly when the wheel was uploaded, but rendered correctly when only the sdist was uploaded.

[Tracking this down](https://github.com/pypa/twine/issues/227#issuecomment-275659758), it turns out that creating the METADATA in the wheel mangles the description un-renderable if a line just so happens to start with "From" *and* be a header. 

wheel uses `email.generator` to write the METADATA file. By default, `email.generator` will write files compatible with Unix mbox format, which means that lines that begin with "From" are mangled to be ">From" (to indicate that they do not begin a new message in the multi-message mbox format). (sdists don't have this problem because the description is in a "header" and headers aren't mangled.)

The METADATA file can only ever be one message, so this is not a concern. (Even if it was, the pkginfo library uses `email.parser` to read the METADATA files, which doesn't support this convention.)

## Example

Mangling "From" to ">From" causes rendering issues when the line happens to be a header. 

Take this perfectly correct RST document:
```
======
 Head
======

Body 1


From Place
----------

A place
```

Mangle the from line:
```
======
 Head
======

Body 1


>From Place
----------

A place
```

Increasing the length of the line makes the underline too short and rendering fails with "Bad.rst:17: (WARNING/2) Title underline too short." (This was verified using `rstview` which uses `readme-renderer`.)

# Proposed Fix

The simple fix is to pass `mangle_from_=False` to the `email.generator.Generator` object used to write the file (in wheel.pkginfo.write_pkg_info, I think). This eliminates the mangling. This parameter is available [all the way back to 2.6](https://docs.python.org/release/2.6/library/email.generator.html).

Originally reported by: **René Dudfield (Bitbucket: [illume](https://bitbucket.org/illume), GitHub: [illume](https://github.com/illume))**

----------------------------------------

For python 3, the `__init__.py` is not required for a package. See pep 420, Implicit namespace packages: https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0420/

However bdist_wheel fails to include the files.

Here is what I've found out so far...


If your package has these files everything is ok when constructing the .whl:

```

Without `__init__.py` the .whl file will not contain the source code. But the sdist copies the source correctly into the tar.gz

I forked the pypa sampleproject and removed the init.py. https://github.com/illume/sampleproject

```
git clone https://github.com/illume/sampleproject.git
cd sampleproject
python3.6 setup.py bdist_wheel

It could be both find_packages and MANIFEST.in handling are broken.

Without MANIFEST.in containing these include lines below, the sdist does not work either. This makes me think that the find_packages is broken in both cases.

items.title: Wheel install code clobbers already-installed files, resulting in damage-via-symlink
items.body:
Originally reported by: **Michał Górny (Bitbucket: [mgorny](https://bitbucket.org/mgorny), GitHub: [mgorny](https://github.com/mgorny))**

----------------------------------------

The wheel code opens files on the live file system for writing directly in many spots. Most importantly, it does that in wheel/install.py:

    destination = HashingFile(open(dest, 'wb'))

This means that for any file installed by the wheel, the code *directly opens and truncates* the potentially existing file in the filesystem. If dest is a symlink, the symlink target is clobbered instead of the symlink being replaced. If dest is a hardlink, all linked files are clobbered. If dest would be a named pipe, wheel would hang waiting for the other end to open. If dest was a block device, wheel would happily start overwriting its contents.

The correct fix is to use (named) temporary files when writing, and move them over the original files afterwards (e.g. using `shutil.move()`). This also has the advantage that the original file doesn't get clobbered if the write fails.

The easy fix to add `os.unlink(dest)` call before opening the file for writing. Unlike the correct solution, it's not properly atomic but it will at least prevent pip from damaging more Gentoo systems by writing into symlinks to system components.

----------------------------------------
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/pypa/wheel/issue/176
